DT Article
TI A review of the macrochelid mites of Turkey (Acari: Macrochelidae), with
   new records and descriptions of three new species.
AU Ozbek, Hasan Husseyin (hozbek@erzincan.edu.tr) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 3
PS 559-572
PD Sep 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB This study reviews the family Macrochelidae in Turkey, with new
   information about species diversity. Nothrholaspis scutivagus sp. nov.,
   Macrocheles niksarensis sp. nov. and Holostaspella bidentata sp. nov.
   are described as new species from Turkey. Nothrholaspis scutivagus has a
   characteristic dorsal shield chaetotaxy, and post-genital platelets that
   are sometimes fused to the ventri-anal shield. Macrocheles niksarensis
   has 29 pairs of pilose dorsal shield setae and a machete-like cheliceral
   dorsal seta. The genus Holostaspella is recorded from Turkey for the
   first time, on the basis of H. bidentata. Macrocheles peniculatus and M.
   insignitus are reported from Turkey for the first time. Also,
   Macrholaspis recki and M. evansi are presented here with some notes on
   the Turkish specimens.
C1 Ozbek, Hasan Husseyin; Erzincan Univ, Fac Sci & Arts, Erzincan, Turkey,
   Turkey.
EM hozbek@erzincan.edu.tr

    / New record].

AB The Serra da Mocidade National Park is a conservation area located in
   one of the most inaccessible portions of Amazonia Biome in the Roraima
   State. The first survey of aquatic insects from that in this region was
   undertaken in January to February 2016 and we present a checklist of
   eight species of the Leptophlebiidae (Ephemeroptera) found in the Park
   and describe three new species of Miroculis based on male imagos.

   India. This is the third member of the genus Bregmatothrips with forked

DT Article
TI Big and beautiful: the Megaxyela species (Hymenoptera, Xyelidae) of East
   Asia and North America.
AU Blank, Stephan M. (sblank@senckenberg.de) 
   Kramp, Katja
   Smith, David R.
   Sundukov, Yuri N.
   Wei, Meicai
   Shinohara, Akihiko
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 348
PS 1-46
PD Sep 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Megaxyela Ashmead, 1898 comprises 13 species, four of which are
   described as new and one is removed from synonymy: Megaxyela euchroma
   Blank, Shinohara & Wei sp. nov. from China (Zheijang), M. fulvago Blank,
   Shinohara & Wei sp. nov. from China (Hunan, Jiangsu, Zhejiang), M.
   inversa Blank & D.R. Smith sp. nov. from the USA (West Virginia), M.
   langstoni Ross, 1936 sp. rev. from the eastern USA, and M. pulchra
   Blank, Shinohara & Sundukov sp. nov. from China (Hubei, Jilin, Liaoning,
   Shaanxi, Tibet), South Korea (Kangwon-do) and Russia (Primorskiy Kray).
   The male of M. parki Shinohara, 1992 is described for the first time. A
   lectotype is designated for M. gigantea Mocsary, 1909. A cladogram,
   based on COI sequences of seven species, is presented and interpreted in
   view of selected morphological characters. Records of M. fulvago sp.
   nov. from Hunan and of M. pulchra sp. nov. from Tibet extend the known
   distribution of Megaxyela in the Old World 600 kilometers farther south
   and 2500 kilometers farther west than previous records.

   Muncheberg, D-15374, Germany, Germany.

PT J
AN ZOOR15505026282
PM 28890856
DT Article
TI The semi-aquatic pondweed bugs of a Cretaceous swamp.
AU Sanchez-Garcia, Alba
   Nel, Andre
   Arillo, Antonio
   Solorzano Kraemer, Monica M. (monica.solorzano-kraemer@senckenberg.de) 
SO PeerJ
VL 5
PS e3760
PD Sep 5 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Pondweed bugs (Herniptera: Mesoveliidae), considered a sister group to
   all other Gerromorpha, are exceedingly rare as fossils. Therefore, each
   new discovery of a fossil mesoveliid is of high interest, giving new
   insight into their early evolutionary history and diversity and enabling
   the testing of their proposed relationships. Here, we report the
   discovery of new mesoveliid material from Spanish Lower Cretaceous
   (Albian) amber, which is the first such find in Spanish amber. To date,
   fossil records of this family only include one species from French
   Kimmeridgian as compression fossils, two species in French amber
   (Albian-Cenomanian boundary), and one in Dominican amber (Miocene). The
   discovery of two males and one female described and figured as
   Glaesivelia pultherrima Sanchez-Garcia & Solorzano Kraemer gen. et sp.
   n., and a single female described and figured as Iberovelia quisquilia
   Sanchez-Garcia & Nel, gen. et sp. n., reveals novel combinations of
   traits related to some genera currently in the subfamily Mesoveliinae.
   Brief comments about challenges facing the study of fossil mesoveliids
   are provided, showing the necessity fora revision of the existing
   phylogenetic hypotheses. Some of the specimens were studied using
   infrared microscopy, a promising alternative to the systematic study of
   organisms preserved in amber that cannot be clearly visualised. The new
   taxa significantly expand the fossil record of the family and shed new
   light on its palaeoecology. The fossils indicate that Mesoveliidae were
   certainly diverse by the Cretaceous and that numerous tiny cryptic
   species living in humid terrestrial to marginal aquatic habitats remain
   to be discovered. Furthermore, the finding of several specimens as
   syninclusions suggests aggregative behaviour, thereby representing the
   earliest documented evidence of such ethology.
C1 Solorzano Kraemer, Monica M.; Senckenberg Forschungsinstitut, Palaontol
   & Hist Geol, Frankfurt, Germany, Germany.
EM monica.solorzano-kraemer@senckenberg.de

DT Article
TI Review of Cape Verde Pselactus Broun, 1886 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae:
   Cossoninae) with description of a new species, larvae and notes on
   biology.
AU Skuhrovec, Jiri (jirislavskuhrovec@gmail.com) 
   Hlavac, Peter
   Batelka, Jan
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 225-246
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Pselactus in the Cape Verde Islands is reviewed. Pselactus
   obesulus (Wollaston, 1867) from Sao Vicente is redescribed and P.
   strakai sp. nov. from Sao Nicolau is described. Both species are
   diagnosed and illustrated; their larvae are described, larval morphology
   is discussed and the current state of knowledge about immature stages of
   Cossoninae is summarized. The systematic position of the genus within
   Onycholipini is reviewed, and the placement of genus in Cossoninae is
   discussed. A short note on biogeography of Pselactus is provided.
C1 Skuhrovec, Jiri; Crop Res Inst, Grp Funct Invertebrate & Plant Biodivers
   Agroecos, Prague, Ruzyne, 6, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM jirislavskuhrovec@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Three new species of Cladorhiza (Demospongiae, Poecilosclerida,
   Cladorhizidae) from the Northeast Pacific Ocean.
AU Lundsten, Lonny
   Reiswig, Henry M.
   Austin, William C.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 247-260
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Carnivorous feeding among the Cladorhizidae (Porifera, Demospongiae,
   Poecilosclerida) was first documented in 1995. Since that time, 161
   species have been described and are currently recognized in 9 genera.
   Cladorhiza is the most speciose genus with a global, deep-water
   distribution of 41 species. Here we describe three new Cladorhiza
   species of 'crinorhiza' form from the Northeast Pacific Ocean off
   California, USA, and the Gulf of California, Mexico, from depths of
   24724100m. In total, 11 specimens were collected between 1969 and 2015.
   Video recordings from remotely operated vehicles yield additional
   information on habitat type, geographic distribution, and abundance for
   some of these species.
C1 Lundsten, Lonny; Monterey Bay Aquarium Res Inst, 7700 Sandholdt Dr, Moss
   Landing, CA, 95039, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Cladorhiza hubbsi; Cladorhiza kensmithi [North Pacific / USA, California
   / New species]. 
   Cladorhiza mexicana [North Pacific / Mexico / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Cladorhiza hubbsi (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, USA, California (marine), P.
   255]. 
   Cladorhiza kensmithi (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, USA, California (marine),
   P. 250]. 
   Cladorhiza mexicana (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 253].

DT Article
TI A new species of treefrog of the genus Ptychohyla (Anura: Hylidae) from
   Southern Mexico.
AU Canseco-Marquez, Luis
   Luis Aguilar-Lopez, J. (jlal.herp@gmail.com) 
   Luria-Manzano, Ricardo
   Pineda, Eduardo
   Caviedes-Solis, Itzue W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 279-290
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 14
AB We describe a new species of treefrog of the genus Ptychohyla from
   southern Mexico occurring to the east of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec.
   This new species can be distinguished from Mexican congeners by a
   combination of a pale pink iris and the presence of nuptial excrescences
   in breeding males. Including this new taxon, the number of species of
   Ptychohyla increases to 14, with seven of these occurring in Mexico. The
   new species is relatively common in pristine tropical forests, but
   appears to be sensitive to habitat degradation and has not been found in
   human modified habitats, suggesting that habitat modification is a
   threat for this hylid frog.
C1 Luis Aguilar-Lopez, J.; Inst Ecol AC, Red Biol & Conservac Vertebrados,
   Carretera Antigua Coatepec 351, Xalapa, Veracruz, 91070, Mexico, Mexico.
EM jlal.herp@gmail.com
RI Pineda, Eduardo/N-5254-2014
OI Pineda, Eduardo/0000-0002-1997-9576; Luria Manzano,
   Ricardo/0000-0002-1539-479X
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Ptychohyla [Mexico /  / Distribution] [ / Veracruz / New record]. 
   Ptychohyla zoque [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI A new wide-headed Fanged Frog of the Limnonectes kuhlii group (Anura:
   Dicroglossidae) from western Borneo with a redescription of Rana
   conspicillata Guenther, 1872.
AU Dehling, J. Maximilian (dehling@uni-koblenz.de) 
   Dehling, D. Matthias
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 291-309
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We re-examined the type series of Rana conspicillata Gunther, 1872 from
   Matang in western Sarawak, Borneo and found it to consist of specimens
   of three distinct species that can be separated by qualitative
   morphological characters and morphometrics. We re-allocate one
   paralectotype to Limnonectes hikidai and another to a large-sized
   species from western Borneo that we describe as new. The new species is
   morphologically distinguished from all described species of the L.
   kuhlii group from the Sunda region by body size, extent of toe webbing,
   head size and odontoid shape. It differs genetically from all described
   species for which genetic information is available. In order to
   facilitate the further taxonomic revision of the L. kuhlii group on
   Borneo, we provide a detailed morphological redescription of the
   holotype of Rana conspicillata.
C1 Dehling, J. Maximilian; Univ Koblenz Landau, AG Zool, Univ Str 1,
   Koblenz, D-56070, Germany, Germany.
EM dehling@uni-koblenz.de
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Limnonectes kong [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Limnonectes conspicillatus - (Guenther 1872) (Ranidae): [Redescription,
   P. 295; Removal from synonymy, With Limnonectes kuhlii (Tschudi 1838),
   p. 307]. 
   Limnonectes kong (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 300]. 
   Limnonectes kuhlii - (Tschudi 1838) (Ranidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Limnonectes conspicillatus (Guenther 1872), p. 307].

AB Three new species of the subgenus Duolandrevus (Eulandrevus) Gorochov
   from China are described and illustrated, D. (E.) ziyunensis sp. nov.,
   D. (E.) gorochovi sp. nov. and D. (E.) axinus sp. nov. The description
   of previously unknown female of D. (E.) hainanensis Liu, He & Ma, 2015
   is given. D. (E.) infuscatus Liu & Bi, 2010, stat. nov. is transferred
   from the subgenus Duolandrevus (Duolandrevus) Kirby, 1906 to
   Duolandrevus (Eulandrevus). A key of the Chinese species and a
   distribution map of the subgenus Duolandrevus (Eulandrevus) in the world
   are provided.

TI A review of Labidostomis species similar to L. longimana from
   southeastern Europe with descriptions of two new species from Greece and
   Turkey (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Cryptocephalinae: Clytrini).
AU Bezdek, Jan (bezdek@mendelu.cz) 
   Regalin, Renato
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 321-337
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This publication reviews the Labidostomis species from Southeastern
   Europe similar to L. longimana. Two new species, L. daccordii sp. nov.
   (Central Greece) and L. leonardii (Greece: Kos Island, Turkey), are
   described. The type specimens of L. balcanica Tomov, 1987 (Croatia), L.
   graeca Tomov, 1990 and L. tymphristica Tomov, 1990 (both from Greece)
   were studied, all three species are confirmed as valid and their
   diagnostic characters are described. The aedeagus sclerites are
   introduced as useful character to separate Labidostomis species.

DT Article
TI Gibocercus Szumik and Biguembia Szumik (Embioptera, Archembiidae): new
   species and the potentiality of female traits.
AU Szumik, Claudia (szu.claudia@gmail.com) 
   Gandolfo, Raquel
   Pereyra, Veronica
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 338-354
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new species of Biguembia Szumik (B. mirador n. sp. and B. troncol n.
   sp.) and one new species of Gibocercus Szumik (G. podamita n. sp.) from
   Brazil are described and illustrated. The female of Gibocercus chaco
   Szumik is described for the first time. Female terminalia of both genera
   are redefined and redescribed for B. copo, G. chaco and G. beni.
   Additionally, a cladistic analysis using almost 100 morphological
   characters was developed. Both genera appear monophyletic and well
   supported by several synapomorphies. The results also indicate that some
   species are unjustified and therefore they are synonymized: Gibocercus
   magnus Ross, 2001 = Gibocercus beni Szumik, 1997; Gibocercus flavipes
   Ross, 2001 = Gibocercus nanai Szumik, 1997; Gibocercus napoa Ross, 2001
   = Gibocercus sandrae Ross, 2001, all new synonymies. The relationships
   of the new species are discussed as well as the potentiality of female
   traits.
C1 Szumik, Claudia; Fdn Miguel Lillo, Consejo Nacl Invest Cient & Tecn,
   Miguel Lillo 251, Sm De Tucuman, RA-4000, Argentina, Argentina.
EM szu.claudia@gmail.com
OI Szumik, Claudia/0000-0001-5361-0580
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy;
   General morphology; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America
DE Biguembia; Gibocercus [General morphology /  / systematics] [Phylogeny /
   Cladistic analysis / ] [South America /  / ]. 
   Biguembia mirador; Biguembia troncol; Gibocercus podamita [Brazil /  /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Embioptera
OR Biguembia - Szumik 1997 (Embioptera): [Emended diagnosis, Female
   terminalia, p. 342]. 
   Biguembia copo - Szumik 1997 (Embioptera): [Redescription, Female, p.
   353]. 
   Biguembia mirador (Embioptera): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 350]. 
   Biguembia troncol (Embioptera): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 351]. 
   Gibocercus - Szumik 1997 (Embioptera): [Emended diagnosis, Female
   terminalia, p. 342]. 
   Gibocercus beni - Szumik 1997 (Embioptera): [Redescription, Female, p.

AB The genus Euryobeidia Fletcher, 1979 is reviewed. Five species from
   China are recognized, of which, E. ellipsoidea sp. nov., E. incrassata

AN ZOOR15311072942
DT Article
TI A new species of smooth-skinned Spinomantis frog (Anura: Mantellidae)
   from south-eastern Madagascar.
AU Vences, Miguel (m.vences@tu-bs.de) 
   Koehler, Joern
   Glaw, Frank
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 379-390
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB We present molecular evidence for the presence of two species
   morphologically similar to Spinomantis bertini in Ando-hahela National
   Park, south-eastern Madagascar, differing by 5.5-6.3% pairwise DNA
   sequence divergences in the mitochondrial 16S rRNA gene. One of these
   was observed at higher elevations of ca. 1650 m above sea level, whereas
   the other was found at lower elevations of ca. 715 m a.s.l., close to
   the type locality of S. bertini (Isaka-Ivondro), and in one other
   location (Andreoky, ca. 1050 a.s.l.). We herein assign these low-to
   mid-elevation specimens to S. bertini based on their occurrence near the
   type locality and general agreement in colour pattern with the type
   specimen of Gephyromantis bertini Guibe, 1947. The high-elevation form
   is described as Spinomantis beckei sp. nov. based on its molecular
   divergence and reciprocal monophyly with respect to S. bertini, lower
   expression of greenish dorsal colour and less distinct frenal stripe.
   Based on a comparison of published call descriptions for S. bertini and
   our recordings of S. beckei, we hypothesize that S. bertini has a lower
   note repetition rate in advertisement calls. Molecular data suggest that
   the S. bertini species complex is more diverse than previously
   recognized, with at least two more candidate species identified: S. sp.
   Ca7 from Ranomafana National Park, and a newly identified candidate
   species S. sp. Ca12 from Pic d'Ivohibe Special Reserve.
C1 Vences, Miguel; Tech Univ Braunschweig, Zool Inst, Mendelssohnstr 4,
   Braunschweig, D-38106, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Notes on Kocourekia Boucek (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae: Tetrastichinae)
   with description of a new species from China.
AU Cao, Huan-Xi
   La Salle, John
   Fornoff, Felix
   Guo, Peng-Fei
   Zhu, Chao-Dong (caohuanxi@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4317
IS 2
PS 391-400
PD Sep 4 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Kocourekia fusis Cao & Zhu sp. n. (Hymenoptera, Eulophidae) is described
   and illustrated as a parasitoid of aculeate Hymenoptera. Females differ
   from those of the other two species in Kocourekia by the presence of a
   malar sulcus, prompting a re-examination of generic limits. A
   re-definition of Kocourekia is presented, its relationship with other
   closely allied genera in the Melittobia complex is discussed, and a key
   to the species of Kocourekia is provided.

DT Article
TI First faunal insights from biozone Db (middle Miocene, middle Aragonian)
   of the Madrid Basin (Spain).
AU Hernandez-Ballarin, Veronica (verohernandez@mncn.csic.es) 
   Oliver, Adriana
   Antonio Cardaba, Juan
   Presumido, Maria
   Pelaez-Campomanes, Pablo
SO Journal of Iberian Geology
VL 43
IS 3
PS 451-466
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Purpose Palaeontological excavations following public works around the
   Manzanares River in the metropolitan area of Madrid yielded new small
   mammal fossil remains from two locations. We present here a description
   of their rodent assemblages, and a biostratigraphical and
   palaeoecological context of them. A comparison of these levels to the
   contemporaneous fossil localities of the Calatayud-Montalban Basin and
   to other middle Aragonian sites from Madrid is also shown. Material A
   total of 371 dental elements have been studied from the five levels of
   the two locations (Puente de Praga site and Madrid Rio2 site). Results
   The rodent associations from the five new levels are similar and
   comprise eight taxa: Megacricetodon primitivus, Megacricetodon
   vandermeuleni, Democricetodon moralesi, Democricetodon sp., Armantomys
   aragonensis, Microdyromys koenigswaldi, Pseudodryomys ibericus and
   Heteroxerus rubricati. It represents a low equitable rodent community
   characterized by the predominance of the genus Megacricetodon and a
   poorly-represented fauna of glirids and sciurids. Conclusions The fossil
   association and its biostratigraphical markers indicate a correlation of
   the levels to the upper part of biozone Db, this being the first time
   that the rodent assemblages of this biozone are described in the Madrid
   Basin. Based on the rodent content we suggest more humid or/and more
   closed environments in biozone Db than in biozones Dc and Dd. The
   Calatayud-Montalban record shows more diverse rodent assemblages in
   biozone Db, with taxa not recorded in Madrid that are indicative of more
   humid or structured environments. Therefore, the Madrid associations
   would represent dryer or/and more open environments than the
   Calatayud-Montalban associations.

   Gutierrez Abascal 2, Madrid, E-28006, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Integrative species delimitation of the widespread North American
   jumping mice (Zapodinae).
AU Malaney, Jason L. (malaneyj@apsu.edu) 
   Demboski, John R.
   Cook, Joseph A.
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 114
PS 137-152
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 21
AB Delimiting species can be challenging, but is a key step for the
   critical examination of evolutionary history and for prioritizing
   conservation efforts. Because systematic relationships are often
   determined iteratively using tests based on taxonomy, such methods can
   fail to detect cryptic variation and result in biased conclusions.
   Conversely, discovery-based approaches provide a powerful way to define
   operational taxonomic units and test species boundaries. We compare both
   approaches (taxonomy-based delimitation - TBD and discovery-based
   delimitation - DBD) within North American jumping mice (Zapodinae) using
   broad sampling, multilocus analyses, and ecological tests. This group
   diversified through the dynamic glacial-interglacial periods of the
   Quaternary and phylogeographic tests reveal 28 lineages that correspond
   poorly with current taxonomy (4 species, 32 nominal subspecies).
   However, neither the 4-species or 28-lineage hypotheses are optimal for
   species-level classification. Rather, information theoretic approaches
   (Bayes Factors) indicate a 15-species hypothesis is best for
   characterizing genetic variation in this group, with subsequent
   iterative pairwise ecological tests failing to confirm four species
   pairs. Taken together, evolutionary and ecological tests capture
   divergence among 11 putative species that, if upheld by additional
   tests, will lead to taxonomic revision and reevaluation of conservation
   plans. (C) 2017 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Convergent and unidirectional evolution of extremely long aedeagi in the
   largest feather mite genus, Proctophyllodes (Acari: Proctophyllodidae):
   Evidence from comparative molecular and morphological phylogenetics.
AU Klimov, Pavel B. (pklimov@umich.edu) 
   Mironov, Sergey V.
   OConnor, Barry M.
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 114
PS 212-224
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 27
AB Proctophyllodid feather mites (400+ species) are permanent (full-time)
   symbionts commonly occurring on passerine birds. Phenotypic evolution of
   these mites appears to be greatly influenced by characters related to
   reproduction (>87.5% of a total of 32 taxonomically important discrete
   characters) and male genitalic characters (21.9%). Because sexual
   selection could the major evolutionary driver in this system, we test
   the theoretical expectation that genitalic or sexually dimorphic
   characters should evolve more rapidly and divergently then other
   characters. We inferred a time-calibrated molecular phylogeny (6 genes,
   8571 nt aligned, no missing data) for 133 taxa of proctophyllodid mites
   and 40 outgroups. Comparisons of the average number of character state
   changes inferred on 10,696 Bayesian stationary trees indicate that male
   genitalic or sexually dimorphic characters do not evolve significantly
   faster than other characters (p = 0.537 and p = 0.819, respectively).
   However, among the male genitalic characters, a trait related to the
   relative length of the aedeagus experienced extremely fast rates of
   evolution and was detected as a statistical outlier. In this character,
   the transitions between short, long, and several intermediate states
   occurred in both directions. In contrast, the evolution of extremely
   long aedeagi (nearly as long as the body) occurred unidirectionally and
   irreversibly. This surprising result may be due to constraints imposed
   by the female spermathecal canal, which, in species where males have
   extremely long aedeagi, is also very long and may impede pumping sperm
   by short aedeagi. In proctophyllodid mites, extremely long aedeagi
   evolved independently five times in five different monophyletic
   lineages. Several of these lineages were lumped together by taxonomists
   to form easy-to-distinguish but apparently artificial species-groups.
   Male genitalic characters, thus, can introduce false synapomorphies that
   could affect morphology-based phylogenetic inference. For the most
   species-rich genus, Proctophyllodes, we develop a predictive
   classification of species-groups that reconciles molecular and
   morphological data. (C) 2017 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
C1 Klimov, Pavel B.; Univ Michigan, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol, 1109
   Geddes Ave, Ann Arbor, MI, 48109, USA, USA.
EM pklimov@umich.edu

SN 1055-7903

   Reproductive system; Genetics; Evolution; Evolutionary adaptation;
   Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts

DT Article
TI A phylogeny of Southern Hemisphere whelks (Gastropoda: Buccinulidae) and
   concordance with the fossil record.
AU Vaux, Felix (f.vaux@massey.ac.nz) 
   Hills, Simon F.K.
   Marshall, Bruce A.
   Trewick, Steven A.
   Morgan-Richards, Mary
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 114
PS 367-381
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB Under current marine snail taxonomy, the majority of whelks from the
   Southern Hemisphere (Buccinulidae) are hypothesised to represent a
   monophyletic Glade that has evolved independently from Northern
   Hemisphere taxa (Buccinidae). Phylogenetic analysis of mitochondrial
   genomic and nuclear ribosomal DNA sequence data indicates that Southern
   Hemisphere taxa are not monophyletic, and results suggest that dispersal
   across the equator has occurred in both directions. New Zealand
   buccinulid whelks, noted for their high endemic diversity, are also
   found to not be monophyletic. Using independent fossil calibrations,
   estimated genetic divergence dates show remarkable concordance with the
   fossil record of the Penion and Kelletia. The divergence dates and the
   geographic distribution of the genera through time implies that some
   benthic marine snails are capable of dispersal over long distances,
   despite varied developmental strategies. Phylogenetic results also
   indicate that one species, P. benthicolus belongs in Antarctoneptunea.
   (C) 2017 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
C1 Vaux, Felix; Massey Univ, Inst Agr & Environm, Palmerston North, New
   Zealand, New Zealand.

TI Latuitidae nautiloids from the Datianba Formation (Uppermost Darriwilian
   to Sandbian, Ordovician) in western Hunan Province and its ontogenical
   study.
AU Fang, Xiang (xfang@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Chen, Ting-en
   Zhang, Yun-bai
   Li, Wen-jie
   Zhang, Yuan-dong
SO Acta Palaeontologica Sinica
VL 56
IS 3
PS 331-346
PD September 2017

PT J
AN ZOOR15407037092
PM 29080613
DT Article
TI Phylogeography, genetic variability and structure of Acanthamoeba
   metapopulations in Iran inferred by 18S ribosomal RNA sequences: A
   systematic review and meta-analysis.
AU Spotin, Adel (Adelespotin@gmail.com) 
   Moslemzadeh, Hamid Reza
   Mahami-Oskouei, Mahmoud
   Ahmadpour, Ehsan
   Niyyati, Maryam
   Hejazi, Seyed Hossein
   Memari, Fatemeh
   Noori, Jafar
SO Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Medicine
VL 10
IS 9
PS 855-863
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Objective: To verify phylogeography and genetic structure of
   Acanthamoeba populations among the Iranian clinical isolates and
   natural/ artificial environments distributed in various regions of the
   country. Methods: We searched electronic databases including Medline,
   PubMed, Science Direct, Scopus and Google Scholar from 2005 to 2016. To
   explore the genetic variability of Acanthamoeba sp, 205 sequences were
   retrieved from keratitis patients, immunosuppressed cases and
   environmental sources as of various geographies of Iran. Results: T4
   genotypewas the predominant strain in Iran, and the rare genotypes
   belonged to T2, T3, T5 (Acanthamoeba lenticulata), T6, T9, T11, T13 and
   T15 (Acanthamoeba jacobsi). A total of 47 unique haplotypes of T4 were
   identified. A parsimonious network of the sequence haplotypes
   demonstrated star-like feature containing haplogroups IR6 (34.1%) and
   IR7 (31.2%) as the most common haplotypes. In accordance with the
   analysis of molecular variance, the high value of haplotype diversity
   (0.612-0.848) of Acanthamoeba T4 represented genetic variability within
   populations. Neutrality indices of the 18S ribosomal RNA demonstrated
   negative values in all populationswhich represented a considerable
   divergence from neutrality. The majority of genetic diversity belonged
   to the infected contact lens and dust samples in immunodeficiency and
   ophthalmology wards, which indicated potential routes for exposure to a
   pathogenic Acanthamoeba sp. in at-risk individuals. A pairwise fixation
   index (FST) was from low to high values (0.02433-0.41892). The
   statistically FST points out that T4 is genetically differentiated
   between north-west, north-south and centralsouth metapopulations, but
   not differentiated between west-central, west-south, centralsouth, and
   north-central isolates. Conclusions: An occurrence of IR6 and IR7
   displays that possibly a gene flow of Acanthamoeba T4 occurred after the
   founder effect or bottleneck experience through ecological changes or
   host mobility. This is the first systematic review and meta-analysis
   providing new approaches into gene migration and transmission patterns
   of Acanthamoeba sp, and targeting at the high-risk individuals/sources
   among the various regions of Iran.
C1 Spotin, Adel; Tabriz Univ Med Sci, Immunol Res Ctr, Tabriz, Iran, Iran.
EM Adelespotin@gmail.com
RI Hejazi, Seyed Hossein/V-7088-2017; Ahmadpour, Ehsan/K-2514-2017;
   Mahami-Oskouei, Mahmoud/L-3913-2017; Spotin, Adel/C-2275-2015
OI Ahmadpour, Ehsan/0000-0003-1202-6147; Mahami-Oskouei,
   Mahmoud/0000-0001-5169-5429; Spotin, Adel/0000-0002-3009-9537; hejazi,
   seyed hossein/0000-0002-3733-1220
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Documentation; Publications; Biochemistry; Genetics;
   Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Acanthamoeba [Literature review /  / ] [Nucleic acids / 18S rRNA
   sequence / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Population genetics /
   Population genetic structure / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ]
   [Variation / Genetic diversity / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Iran /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Lobosea, Gymnamoebia,
   Amoebida
OR Acanthamoeba (Amoebida).

TI Revision of the tribe Cerambycini: the genus Cyriopalus Pascoe, 1866
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Vitali, Francesco
   Gouverneur, Xavier
   Chemin, Gerard
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 27
PS 10-22
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Cyriopalus Pascoe, 1866 is revised. Three new species,
   Cyriopalus befui n. sp. from continental Malaysia, Cyriopalus javanus n.
   sp. from Java (Indonesia) and Cyriopalus kalimantanus n. sp. from
   Kalimantan (Borneo, Indonesia) are described. Lateropalus n. gen. for
   Cyriopalus pascoei Thomson, 1878 is proposed. Lateropalus pascoei
   (Thomson, 1878) n. comb. is introduced. Lateropalus continentalis n. sp.
   from Vietnam and Laos is described.

DT Article
TI New species, new synonym, notes and designation of lectotypes in
   Taeniotes Audinet-Serville, 1835 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Santos-Silva, Antonio (toncriss@uol.com.br) 
   Tavakilian, Gerard-Luc
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 27
PS 38-58
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taeniotes relucens sp. nov. from Peru, Bolivia and Brazil (Amazonas,
   Para, Rondonia, Distrito Federal, Mato Grosso do Sul) is described. The
   new species corresponds to Taeniotes amazonum Thomson, 1857 sensu
   auctorum. Taeniotes monnei Martins & Santos-Silva, 2012 and T. scalaris
   azoricus Kolbe, 1888 are synonymized with T. amazonum. Taeniotes affinis
   Breuning, 1935 is confirmed as a species distinct from T. naevius Bates,
   1872. A key to species of Taeniotes with general appearance similar to T
   amazonum is provided. Lectotypes are designated for Hammoderus batesi
   Thomson, 1879, T. amazonum, I cayennensis Thomson, 1859, T. inquinatus
   Thomson, 1857, 1 suturalis Thomson, 1857, T. orbignyi Guerin-Meneville,
   1844, T. xanthostictus var. zunilensis Bates, 1885, and Monochamus
   (Taeniotes) decoratus Laporte, 1840. The holotypes of the following
   species are figured for the first time: T. insularis Thomson, 1857, T.
   leucogrammus Thomson, 1865, T. luciani Thomson, 1859, and T. marmoratus
   Thomson, 1865.
C1 Santos-Silva, Antonio; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42391,
   Sao Paulo, SP, BR-04218970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM toncriss@uol.com.br

TI Description of new longhorns from South Africa (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Bjornstad, Anders
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 27
PS 66-81
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New taxa of Cerambycidae from South Africa are described, viz.
   Ethiolygrus aarviki sp. nov. with its subspecies natalensis ssp. nov.
   (Cerambycinae - Oemini), Catoeme gigas sp. nov. (Cerambycinae - Oemini),
   Paracrinarnoldius adlbaueri gen. nov., sp. nov. (Cerambycinae -
   Hesperophanini), Spathuliger continentalis sp. nov. (Cerambycinae
   Obriini), Tlepolemus grobbelaarae sp. nov. (Lamiinae Ceroplesini
   (Crossotina)), and Eunidia muellerae sp. nov. (Lamiinae Eunidiini). New
   distributional records for some species of Catoeme Aurivillius, 1908 are
   given, and the species of Tlepolemus Thomson, 1864 are reviewed and
   illustrated.

DT Article
TI [Twenty-fourth contribution to the study of the African Callichromatini:
   revision of the genus Oxyprosopus Thomson, 1864.]
FT Vingt-quatrieme contribution a letude des Callichromatini africains :
   revision du Genre Oxyprosopus Thomson, 1864 (Cerambycidae,
   Cerambycinae).
AU Juhel, Pierre (juhelpi@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 27
PS 82-115
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Oxyprosopus Thomson is revised. Oxyprosopus brevis Jordan,
   1894 is synonymized with Chromalizus (Callichromalizus) rugosus
   (Aurivillius) n. syn. Litopus cinereipes Chevrolat, 1856 is tranferred
   in the genus Conamblys as Conamblys cinereipes (Chevrolat) rest. stat.
   Oxyprosopus filiformis Harold, 1879 is tranferred in the genus
   Tarsotropidus as Tarsotropidus filiformis Harold n. comb. Oxyprosopus
   calvus Schmidt, 1922 is considered as a subspecies of Oxyprosopus
   coeruleus (Olivier, 1790) n. stat. Oxyprosopus chloreus Bates, 1879 is
   restaured as good species rest. stat., Oxyprosopus cylindricus Bates,
   Oxyprosopus coeruleus amethystinus Schmidt, 1922 and Oxyprosopus
   coeruleus atratus Schmidt, 1922 are considered as sub-species of
   Oxyprosopus chloreus Bates n. stat. Oxyprosopus comis Bates, 1879 is
   synonymized with Oxyprosopus angulicollis Bates, 1879 n. syn.
   Oxyprosopus similis Schmidt, 1922 is synonymized with Oxyprosopus
   angulicollis cyanipes Schmidt, 1922 n. syn. Oxyprosopus similis
   purpurascens Schmidt, 1922 and Oxyprosopus crassus Schmidt, 1922 are
   considered as sub-species of Oxyprosopus angulicollis Bates, 1879 n.
   stat. Oxyprosopus nimbae Lepesme & Breuning is considered as a
   sub-species of Oxyprosopus superbus Schmidt, 1922 n. stat. The new
   taxons Oxyprosopus togoensis n. sp. and Oxyprosopus neavei legalli n.
   ssp. are described.
C1 Juhel, Pierre; 8,Ave Montreal, St Malo, F-35400, France, France.

PT J
AN ZOOR15407040282
DT Article
TI Comparative Study of the Development of Mischocyttarus cassununga Von
   Ihering and Mischocyttarus cerberus styx Richards Colonies (Hymenoptera,
   Vespidae, Mischocyttarini).
AU Biagiotto, Renan Hohendorff (hb.renan@hotmail.com) 
   Shima, Sulene Noriko
SO EntomoBrasilis
VL 10
IS 3
PS 170-177
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Mischocyttarus is a genus of eusocial wasps belonging to the Polistinae
   subfamily. They build nests without envelopes, making it easier to take
   notes and follow the growth of the nest, allowing the observation of
   oviposition, development of the eggs, larvae and pupae, as well as the
   addition of new cells to the nest and hierarchical conflicts among
   adults. Mischocyttarus cerberus styx Richards and Mischocyttarus
   cassununga Von Ihering are representatives of a genus and tribe that
   occur only in the Americas and these species happen to occur in the
   municipality of Rio Claro (SP). The present work aimed to follow the
   development of colonies in order to develop a comparative approach of
   factors that interact with the colony cycle, to verify if the species
   show similar or diverse profiles from each other. Four locations were
   chosen to represent the sampling at the Universidade Estadual Paulista
   campus of Rio Claro, SP. Data collection ranged from April 2014 to April
   2015. M. cerberus styx showed a more irregular profile of productivity
   along the four seasons, presenting in general the greatest values on
   summer and the lowest values on winter. M. cassununga, on the other
   hand, seemed to have a more stable rhythm of productivity, with less
   discrepancy between seasons, demonstrating a better performance
   concerning cold seasons, with the greatest productivity values on spring
   and the lowest values on fall. Both species showed a similar pattern of
   immature development with the shortest period corresponding to summer
   and the longest period corresponding to winter.
C1 Biagiotto, Renan Hohendorff; Univ Estadual Paulista Julio Mesquita Filho
   UNESP, Inst Biociencias, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
EM hb.renan@hotmail.com
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1983-0572
BD Life cycle and development; Abiotic factors; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Mischocyttarus cassununga; Mischocyttarus cerberus styx [Development / 
   / comparative study] [Abiotic factors / Season / ] [Brazil / Sao Paulo,
   Rio Claro municipality / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Vespoidea, Vespidae
OR Mischocyttarus cassununga (Vespidae). 
   Mischocyttarus cerberus styx (Vespidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15407040282
OA Other Gold, Bronze
DA 2020-09-17

AB A new species of genus Inaequalium (Inaequalium pujoli sp. n.) is
   described here, from state of Goias, a macro region called Chapada dos
   Veadeiros, Central Brazil. Also is proposed to change the name It is
   proposed to change the name I. rappae Py-Daniel & Coscaron, because it
   takes on the characteristic of nomen nudum, to Inaequalium rapporum
   Py-Daniel & Coscaron. Comments and characters of Inaequalium rapporum
   are also presented. Two other species, I. maranguapense Pessoa,
   Rios-Velasquez & Py-Daniel and I. margaritatum Pepinelli, Hamada & Luz
   are compared and commented. A key of differentiation to these four
   species is presented.

PT J
AN ZOOR15407040289
DT Article
TI First report of the Aphis craccivora Koch on Catasetum sp in Brazil.
AU Leite, Douglas Machado
   Garlet, Juliana (julianagarlet@yahoo.com.br) 
   Karsburg, Isane Vera
SO EntomoBrasilis
VL 10
IS 3
PS 251-253
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Catasetum (Orchidaceae) currently has 194 orchid species
   distributed throughout Central America, northern Argentina, and southern
   Brazil, with Brazil as the largest producer with 103 species that may be
   epiphytic, terrestrial, or rupicolous. Aphids are insect pests that can
   damage ornamental plants such as orchids, either directly by sucking
   their sap or indirectly via secretions. Their secretions are attractive
   to pathogens and other insects, which then feed on the plant and cause a
   loss of flowers and leaves, spots to appear, reduced flower production,
   and flowering deformation. These defects can then reduce the value of
   the plant. When an aphid attack occurs, their ability to rapidly
   multiply and spread can cause major disruptions to disruptions to parts
   of the plant's life cycle. In this report, we examine how the aphid
   Aphis craccivora Koch infests Catasetum sp. and causes tissue death,
   decay of the buttons and base of the stem, and stains in the flowers.
   Thus, owing to the damage that insects of the family Aphididae can cause
   ornamental plants, this study aims to report the first recorded A.
   craccivora attack on Catasetum sp. in Brazil.
C1 Garlet, Juliana; Univ Estado Mato Grosso, Caceres, MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM julianagarlet@yahoo.com.br
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1983-0572
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Aphis craccivora [Plant hosts / Catasetum / New record; plant damage]
   [Brazil /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Aphidoidea
OR Aphis craccivora (Aphidoidea): [Parasite; New record].

DT Article
TI [The geometer moths of the Dzanga Ndoki national park (Central African
   Republic): correction note (Lepidoptera).]
FT Les Geometridae du Parc national de Dzanga Ndoki (R.C.A) : note
   corrective (Lepidoptera).
AU Sircoulomb, Guy (gns2@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 22
IS 2
PS 13-14
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB In a previous paper the author had described a new species, Cleora
   hausmanni Sircoulomb, 2014, based on two males and a female collected in
   the Central African Republic. But two males from Ivory Coast, in a
   better state (with antennae) have subsequently been closely examined and
   showed identical genitalia, leading the author to assign them to the
   genus Ascotis, and then to the species Ascotis reciprocaria Walker,
   1860. The recent results obtained from the DNA sequencing of the CAR
   males then confirmed that both matched well with the latest species,
   whereas the CAR female belongs to Cleora dactylata Fletcher, 1967. In
   his comparative diagnosis the author had discarded this eventuality
   based on the apparent lack of a membranous sac along the ductus bursae.
   The hypothesis of a partially damaged genitalia is considered: a closer
   examination with high magnification optical material has put in evidence
   a fragment of pellicle, transparent and overlapping the remaining
   cuticle, which was missed during the first observation. This we believe
   to be the remnant of an open torn sac, flattened during the microscopic
   slide mounting. The following synonymy is proposed: Cleora hausmanni
   Sircoulomb, 2014 (holotype and paratype) = Ascotis reciprocaria Walker,
   1860, syn. nov. and the female paratype of Cleora hausmanni Sircoulomb,
   2014 is assigned to Cleora dactylata Fletcher, 1967.
C1 Sircoulomb, Guy; 160 Route Cavee, Anquetierville, F-76490, France,
   France.
EM gns2@wanadoo.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1371-7057
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Geometroidea, Geometridae
OR Ascotis reciprocaria - Walker 1860 (Geometridae): [Syn nov, Cleora
   hausmanni Sircoulomb 2014, p. 14].

DT Article
TI [Revision of Plectogaster Waterhouse, 1881 of the 'jordani group'
   (Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae, Plectogasterini).]
AU Bouyer, Thierry
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 22
IS 2
PS 21-42
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Cerambycidae genus Plectogaster Waterhouse, 1881 is divided into two
   groups, the jordani group Heath, 1905" and the "pectinicornis group
   Bates, 1881". The "jordani group" is revised and all its species are
   represented. To the four existing species, Plectogaster jordani Heath,
   1905, Plectogaster schoutedeni Burgeon, 1947, Plectogaster puncticollis
   Burgeon, 1947 and Plectogaster noellae Bouyer, 2011, are added six new
   species which are described and illustrated: Plectogaster rautenstrauchi
   n. sp. from Cameroon, Plectogaster vingerhoedti n. sp. from Cameroon and
   Ivory Coast, Plectogaster hanoti n. sp. from the Democratic Republic of
   the Congo, Plectogaster nzefianti n. sp. from Cameroon, Gabon, Central
   African Republic, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the People's
   Republic of the Congo, Plectogaster vandeweghei n. sp. from Gabon and
   Plectogaster ripaillei n. sp. from Burkina Faso, from Liberia and Ivory
   Coast.

TI [Contribution to the knowledge of Pachnoda Burmeister, 1842 from
   Ethiopia with a description of a new species and a new subspecies.]

AB Description and illustration of Pachnoda lorinae n. sp which is compared

   nominate sub-species. New biological and bio-geographical data are given
   for these species.

TI CONTRIBUTION TO THE SIBERIAN CHRYSIDIDAE (HYMENOPTERA). PART 2.

AB In this second part, new Elampini records from Siberia are reported, as
   well as the description of 11 new species, namely: Elampus agnolii Rosa,
   sp. n., E. coloratus Rosa, sp. n., Hedychridium belokobylskiji Rosa, sp.
   n., H. gabriellae Rosa, sp. n., H. longigena Rosa, sp. n., H. leleji
   Rosa, sp. n., H. loktionovi Rosa, sp. n., H. propodeale Rosa, sp. n., H.
   proshchalykini Rosa, sp. n., H. arensi Rosa, sp. n., H sibiricum Rosa,
   sp. n. are given. We upgraded to species level Hedychridium asianum
   Linsenmaier, 1997, stat. n. and H. turcicum Arens, 2010, stat. n. A new
   synonymy is proposed: Holopyga generosa asiatica Trautmann, 1926 =
   Holopyga ovata proviridis Linsenmaier, 1959, syn. n. An update
   check-list of the Siberian species is given and distribution by regions
   is discussed.

DT Article
TI Elasmobranch fauna from the upper most part of the Cretaceous Bagh
   Group, Narmada valley, India.
AU Prasad, Guntupalli V.R. (guntupalli.vrprasad@gmail.com) 
   Verma, Vishal
   Sahni, Ashok
   Lourembam, Ranjit S.
   Rajkumari, Priyadarshini
SO Island Arc
VL 26
IS 5
PS e12200
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In India, Cretaceous elasmobranchs are known from the uppermost
   Cretaceous Deccan intertrappean sedimentary sequences of peninsular
   India and the lower Upper Cretaceous (Cenomanian) Karai Formation of the
   Cauvery basin, South India. The intertrappean elasmobranchs are
   represented mainly by rays and skates, whereas the Karai fauna is known
   by hexanchiform, squaliform, and lamniform sharks. The latter assemblage
   is dominated by cool temperate water forms in addition to some
   cosmopolitan forms. Here new shark teeth recovered from the upper part
   of the marine Cretaceous Bagh Group, in the lower Narmada valley,
   Western India are described. This is the first detailed description of
   sharks from the Bagh Group and the first record of sharks from the
   youngest horizons (Coniacian to Late Maastrichtian) of this marine
   sedimentary sequence. The fauna, recovered from an oyster shell-rich
   green sandstone at the top of the youngest geological unit (the
   Coralline Limestone) of the Bagh Group, is assigned to Ptychodus sp.,
   Scapanorhynchus sp. aff. S. raphiodon (Agassiz, 1844), Cretodus sp. aff.
   C. crassidens (Dixon, 1850), Cretalamna sp., Squalicorax sp. aff. S.
   falcatus Agassiz, 1843, and Elasmobranchii indet. This assemblage,
   previously widely documented from the Cretaceous deposits of North and
   South Americas, Europe, North and West Africa, Far East and Near East,
   demonstrates that there is a clear change in elasmobranch faunal
   composition of India from cool temperate water forms in the early Late
   Cretaceous to essentially cosmopolitan forms in the Late Cretaceous.
C1 Prasad, Guntupalli V.R.; Univ Delhi, Dept Geol, Delhi, 110007, India,
   India.
EM guntupalli.vrprasad@gmail.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1038-4871
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Ecology; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Elasmobranchii [Teeth /  / new record; systematics] [Fossil assemblages
   /  / ] [Madhya Pradesh / Narmada valley / ] [Cretaceous / Upper
   Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes
OR Elasmobranchii (Chondrichthyes): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI First record of family Xenasteiidae (Diptera: Brachycera: Cyclorrhapha)
   from India in association with Aleurodicus rugioperculatus Martin
   (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae) with cautionary notes on associated
   parasitoids.
AU Gupta, Ankita (drankitagupta7@gmail.com) 
   Selvaraj, K.
   Wyatt, Nigel
   Rajeshwari, S.K.
   Ballal, C.R.
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 31
IS 3
PS 128-134
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB First ever record of family Xenasteiidae (Diptera: Brachycera:
   Cyclorrhapha) from mainland India is provided. Most of the previous
   records of this family are from coastal sites, as they have usually been
   found on islands in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. For the first time
   biology and life stages of Xenasteia are illustrated. Xenasteia members
   were found associated with an exotic rugose spiraling whitefly (RSW)
   colony of Aleurodicus rugioperculatus Martin (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae) in
   the coastal areas of Karnataka in southern India, however no direct
   obligate association could be diagnosed. Also for the first time
   Ooencyrtus sp. (Hymenoptera: Encyrtidae) was recorded from the genus
   Xenasteia as its solitary parasitoid. Worldwide, this is the first ever
   report of parasitism associated with any member of this little-known
   family Xenasteiidae.
C1 Gupta, Ankita; Natl Bur Agr Insect Resources, ICAR, Post Bag
   2491,Bellary Rd, Bengaluru, Karnataka, 560024, India, India.
EM drankitagupta7@gmail.com

   Asia; India

   systematics] [Karnataka / Udupi, Malpe beach / biology].

DT Article
TI Metarhizium majus and Metarhizium robertsii show enhanced activity
   against the coleopteran pests Holotricha serrata and Oryctes rhinoceros.
AU Velavan, V. (velavan.sv@gmail.com) 
   Sivakumar, G.
   Rangeshwaran, R.
   Sundararaj, R.
   Sasidharan, T.O.
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 31
IS 3
PS 135-145
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Studies were conducted to systematically isolate Metarhizium isolates
   from the insect cadavers and soils of South India. Morphological and PCR
   amplified sequences of 5.8S ITS regions and RNA polymerase II largest
   subunit (RPB1) gene regions were used to identify the isolates at
   species level. Eight Metarhizium isolates were isolated and initially
   identified by morphological and microscopic studies. Further
   identification was confirmed through 5.8SrRNA ITS and RPB1 analysis.
   They were identified as three isolates of M. robertsii J.F. Bisch.,
   Rehner & Humber sp. nov. (ArMz3R, ArMz3S and ArMz6W), one isolate of M.
   majus (J.R. Johnst.) J.F. Bisch., Rehner & Humber (VjMz1W) and four
   isolates of M. anisopliae (WnMz1S, NlMz2S, BgMz2S and DhMz4R). Topical
   conidial suspensions (TCS) and powder based formulations (PBF) of the
   eight indigenous isolates of Metarhizium spp. that were isolated from
   insect cadavers and soils of South India were tested against coleopteran
   pests Holotricha serrata L. and Oryctes rhinoceros L. that cause serious
   damage to sugarcane and palm trees respectively. Against H. serrata TCS
   of M. robertsii (ArMz6W) was the most effective with an LC50 of
   6.893x105 cfu/ml and caused 100% mortality against the 3rd instar larvae
   in 5 days; PBF elicited an LC50 of 7.502x105 cfu/ml with 96% mortality
   in 10 days. Against O. rhinoceros TCS (LC50 of 9.75x105 cfu/ml) of M.
   majus (VjMz1W) caused 90% mortality in 7 days and the PBF (LC50 of
   9.57x105 cfu/ml) caused 86% mortality in 14 days. The results establish
   that M. robertsii is highly effective against H. serrata and against O.
   rhinoceros, M. majus was the most effective. The TCS formulations of
   these two strains can be readily deployed for field applications.
C1 Velavan, V.; Natl Bur Agr Insects Resources, ICAR, Bangalore, Karnataka,
   560024, India, India.
EM velavan.sv@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Infectious Diseases; Mycology
SN 0970-5732

   disorders; Microbial diseases; Ecology; Population dynamics; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Holotrichia serrata; Oryctes rhinoceros [Biological control /  /
   morphological & molecular characterization; larva] [Fungal diseases /
   Metarhizium majus / ] [ / Metarhizium robertsii / ] [Mortality /  / ]
   [India / South / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15407038477
DT Article
TI Rare occurrence of leech infestation in ovary of a cow.
AU Sarmah, P.C.
   Das, A.
   Bhattacharjee, K.
   Deka, B.C.
   Deka, D.K.
   Roy, K.
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 5 G
PS 502-504
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study describes a foreign body that happens to be a leech
   lodged in the ovary of a cow from Assam, India. Briefly, during
   examination of ovaries collected from cattle at slaughter, one of the
   ovaries showed presence of a non-motile worm like dull and dark coloured
   thick and muscular foreign body. It measured 18 mm in length and 3 mm
   width at the broader posterior end. There was presence of annulations on
   the body surface, one small sucker at the narrower end and a large
   posterior sucker at the broader end. Microscopy of the lactophenol
   treated specimen could not reveal much due to its rigidity and
   contractile state. Identification of the specimen as leech was made on
   the basis of morphological findings. The small sized leech was presumed
   to be a terrestrial type (land leech) belonging to the genus Haemadipsa.
   It is suggested that the leech might have gained entry into the host
   through the vagina and thereby uterus to reach one of the ovaries. The
   present finding appears to be the first report of Haemadipsa sp.
   infesting a visceral compact organ in man and animals and adds ovary to
   the list of organs that are documented to be affected by leech.
C1 Sarmah, P.C.; Assam Agr Univ, Coll Vet Sci, Guwahati, Assam, India,
   India.
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Parasitology
BD Reproduction; Reproductive system; Gonad; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India
DE Bos taurus [Ovary /  / case report; new record] [Annelid parasites /
   Haemadipsa / ] [Assam /  / ]. 
   Haemadipsa [Mammalian hosts / Bos taurus / Case report; new record]
   [Assam /  / ]. 
TN Annelids; Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Hirudinea, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia,
   Artiodactyla, Bovidae

   Bos taurus (Bovidae): [Host; New record].

AN ZOOR15407038484
DT Article
TI First report on the outbreak of Argulus sp (Crustacea: Branchiura) at a
   carp seed farm from Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India.
AU Saravanan, K.
   Praveenraj, J.
   Sivaramakrishnan, T.
   Sankar, R. Kiruba
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 5 P
PS 1192-1195
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB In the present study, a disease outbreak with 40% mortality in Catla
   catla and Labeo rohita was investigated at a carp seed farm located at
   South Andaman, India. Various symptoms like abnormal swimming, excessive
   mucus production, fin erosion and slight hemorrhage were observed in the
   affected fishes. Examination of moribund fishes revealed the causative
   agent as Argulus sp. The parasites were found attached to the skin and
   fins of all the examined fishes showing 100% prevalence. Heavy
   infestation of Argulus sp. was observed in C. catla and L. rohita with
   mean individuals of 90 to 130 parasites per fish. Molecular
   characterization of the obtained parasite using 28S rDNA (GenBank
   accession number MF926591) showed 94% sequence identity with Argulus
   japonicus and A. foliaceus, which further confirmed the causative agent.
   This is the first report on the outbreak of Argulus sp. from Andaman and
   Nicobar Islands, which also reveals the pandemic occurrence of Argulus
   sp. even in the freshwater aquatic system of these islands.
C1 Saravanan, K.; ICAR Cent Isl Agr Res Inst, Port Blair, Andaman & Nicob,
   744101, India, India.
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BD Biochemistry; Genetics; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Hosts; Ecology; Population dynamics; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North
   Indian Ocean
DE Argulus [Nucleic acids / 28S rDNA sequences / new record] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ] [Piscean hosts / Catla catla / ] [ / Labeo rohita / ]
   [Bay of Bengal / Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Andaman, south / ]. 
   Catla catla; Labeo rohita [Crustacean parasites / Argulus / New record]
   [Mortality /  / ] [Bay of Bengal / Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Andaman,
   south / ].

   Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii, Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Argulus (Branchiura): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Catla catla (Cyprinidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Labeo rohita (Cyprinidae): [Host; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15407039495
DT Article
TI On the Steinmanellidae (Bivalvia: Myophorelloidea); their
   palaeobiogeography, evolution and classification.
AU Cooper, Michael R. (mikecooper1946@gmail.com) 
   Leanza, Hector A.
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 285
IS 3
PS 313-335
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The trigoniid group "Pseudo-Quadratae" was introduced for Cretaceous
   descendents of Myophorellidae with a convergent resemblance to Tethyan
   Quadratotrigoniinae (= Quadratae). Subsequently it was made the basis of
   the subfamily Steinmanellinae, which herein is elevated to family rank.
   The earliest record of the group is from the Early-Middle Kimmeridgian
   of the Tethyan Realm (American Province), from where it spread into the
   Boreal and Gondwanic realms. Steinmanellids rose to dominance in the
   cool temperate waters of the Andean Province, and the latter represents
   their centre of diversification. They are absent from the predominantly
   cold circum-polar waters of Southern and Eastern Gondwana, i.e. the
   Antarctic and Maorian provinces, as well as from the Australasian
   Province. The evolution of the group is tracked and two lineages
   identified, comprising 47 nominal species assigned to 14 genera, 9 of
   which are new: Stoyanowella, Philippiella, Garatella, Weaverella,
   Neuquenella, Pseudoyaadia, Popenoella, Louella, and Tashiroella. One
   lineage (Yaadiinae nov.) migrated northwards from its Tethyan origin
   into the Cordilleran Province of the Boreal Realm and thence, in the
   Late Cretaceous, to the Oriental Province, surviving in both biochores
   into the Maastrichtian. The second lineage, the subfamily
   Steinmanellinae, appeared in the Early-Middle Kimmeridgian of the
   American Province, but its centre of diversification was in the Andean
   Province where it appeared in the Early Tithonian and survived until the
   Late Hauterivian. From there it migrated eastwards into the Ethiopian
   Province, reaching as far as India, where it is recorded only from the
   Late Valanginian and Barremian.
C1 Cooper, Michael R.; Durban Nat Sci Museum, P Bag 4085, Durban, ZA-4001,
   South Africa, South Africa.
EM mikecooper1946@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0077-7749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type species; Type
   material; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Unavailable
   name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Evolution; Zoogeography;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Garatella; Louella; Neuquenella; Popenoella; Pseudoyaadia; Tashiroella;

   Neuquenella (Trigonioidea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Steinmanellinae, Type

   Neuquenella kensleyi - (Cooper 1979) (Trigonioidea): [Comb nov, Previous

   Transferred from Steinmanella (Macrotrigonia), p. 323]. 
   Packardella - Kobayashi & Amano 1955 (Trigonioidea): [Nomen nudum, P.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of fossil scorpion (?Euscorpiidae) from the
   Early-Middle Eocene of Pesciara (Bolca, Italy).
AU Kuehl, Gabriele (gkuehl@uni-bonn.de) 
   Lourenco, Wilson R.
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 283-290
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Fossil scorpions are among the oldest terrestrial arthropods known from
   the fossil record. They have a worldwide distribution and a rich fossil
   record, especially for the Paleozoic. Fossil scorpions from Mesozoic and
   Cenozoic deposits are usually rare (except in amber-deposits). Here, we
   describe the only fossil scorpion from the Early to Middle Eocene
   Pesciara Lagerstatte in Italy. Eoeuscorpius ceratoi gen. et sp. nov. is
   probably a genus and species within the family Euscorpiidae. This may be
   the first fossil record of the Euscorpiidae, which are so far only known
   from four extant genera. Eoeuscorpius ceratoi gen. et sp. nov. was found
   in the "Lower Part" of the Pesciara Limestone, which is actually dated
   Late Ypresian stage (between 49.5 and 49.7 Ma). Besides a possible
   pseudoscorpion, the here-described fossil scorpion is the second
   arachnid species known from the Bolca Locality.
C1 Kuehl, Gabriele; Steinmann Inst, Div Palaeontol, Nussalle 8, Bonn,
   D-53115, Germany, Germany.
EM gkuehl@uni-bonn.de
SC Zoology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Eoeuscorpius [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Eoeuscorpius ceratoi [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Euscorpiidae [Italy / Bolca, Pesciara / possible first fossil record]
   [Eocene / Early-Middle Eocene / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones

   species Eoeuscorpius ceratoi, p. 285, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Eoeuscorpius ceratoi (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Italy, Eocene, P. 285;
   Fossil]. 
   Euscorpiidae (Scorpiones): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15407036870
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of raninoid crab from the Upper Cretaceous of
   Mississippi.
AU Nyborg, Torrey (tnyborg06@llu.edu) 
   Phillips, George E.
   Van Bakel, Barry
   Vega, Francisco J.
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 291-298
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus and species of raninoid crab, Carinatus galebishopi, is
   described from the upper Maastrichtian Prairie Bluff and Owl Creek
   formations of Mississippi. Carinatus galebishopi gen. et sp. nov. fits
   best within the Raninidae, Subfamily Symethinae, based upon similar
   dorsal carapace characteristics of member genera. The new crab possesses
   distinctive dorsal carapace ornamentation setting it apart from
   described symethines and warrants establishment of a new genus.
   Carinatus galebishopi represents the first Cretaceous symethine crab and
   suggests the subfamily may have migrated eastward across the North
   Atlantic-Maastrichtian of Mississippi, Danian of New Jersey, and
   Ypresian of Spain-before dispersing to the Indo-Pacific.
C1 Nyborg, Torrey; Loma Linda Univ, Dept Earth & Biol Sci, Loma Linda, CA,
   92354, USA, USA.
EM tnyborg06@llu.edu
OI Vega Vera, Francisco Javier/0000-0001-5445-8832

   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Mississippi /  / ] [Cretaceous /  / ].

DT Article
TI The oldest opatrine terrestrial darkling beetle (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae: Tenebrioninae) from the Paleocene of Menat (France).
AU Nabozhenko, Maxim (nalassus@mail.ru) 
   Kirejtshuk, Alexander
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 307-313
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The oldest terrestrial darkling beetle of the opatrine lineage,
   Palaeosclerum pohli gen. et. sp. nov. (subfamily Tenebrioninae) is
   described from the Middle Paleocene of Menat (France). The complex of
   characters, combining the peculiar shape of body (robust, adapted to a
   fossorial lifestyle), structure of fossorial protibia, 5-segmented
   antennal club demonstrates a considerable similarity of the new genus to
   the extant representatives of the 'sclerina' generic group of the
   subtribe Opatrina. Palaeosclerum gen. nov. is compared with recent
   genera Sclerum Dejean, 1834, Platynosum Mulsant and Rey, 1859 and
   Eurycaulus Fairmaire, 1868.

AN ZOOR15407036875
DT Article
TI Goniatites sphaericus (Sowerby, 1814), the archetype of Palaeozoic
   ammonoids: a case of decreasing phenotypic variation through ontogeny.
AU Korn, Dieter (dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de) 
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 337-352
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Late Vis,an (Early Carboniferous) ammonoid species Goniatites
   sphaericus (Sowerby, 1814) is revised with the use of the type material.
   With respect to conch morphology, suture line and particularly shell
   ornament, it is regarded as a senior synonym of the species Goniatites
   fimbriatus (Foord and Crick, 1897) and must therefore be re-established
   as an important index fossil for the ammonoid stratigraphy of the
   Rhenohercynian and Subvariscan shelves. The Goniatites fimbriatus Zone
   has been re-named Goniatites sphaericus Zone on this basis. The study of
   ontogenetic changes in the conch parameters shows that intraspecific
   variation occurs within a wide range. In the whorl profile, variation is
   very high in small juveniles, while in the coiling rate, intermediate
   growth stages are more strongly affected.
C1 Korn, Dieter; Museum Nat Kunde Berlin, Leibniz Inst Evolut &
   Biodiversitatsforsch, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany,
   Germany.
EM dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de
RI Korn, Dieter/B-2963-2009
OI Korn, Dieter/0000-0003-1104-6939
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary
   Biology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Life cycle and development; Evolution; Variation; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic
DE Goniatites sphaericus [Shell morphology /  / systematics] [Development /
   Ontogeny / ] [Morphological variation / Phenotypic variation / ]
   [Carboniferous / Late Visean / ].

   Goniatites fimbriatus (Foord & Crick 1897), p. 347; Fossil].

DT Article
TI The oldest bryozoans of Baltoscandia from the lowermost Floian
   (Ordovician) of north-western Russia: two new rare, small and simple
   species of Revalotrypidae.
AU Fedorov, Petr V. (p.fedorov@spbu.ru) 
   Koromyslova, Anna V.
   Martha, Silviu O.
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 353-373
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe two new species of esthonioporate bryozoans, Revalotrypa
   inopinata sp. nov. and R. yugaensis sp. nov., from the Lower Ordovician,
   south-east of Lake Ladoga, north-western Russia. The colonies of the two
   species are very small and were extracted from limestone nodules found
   in the lower part of glauconitic sandstone in the Joa Member (lowermost
   Floian). Revalotrypa inopinata sp. nov. and R. yugaensis sp. nov. are
   the oldest known bryozoans from Baltoscandia. Study of the two species
   includes scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging and X-ray
   microtomography (micro-CT). The palaeogeographic distribution of the
   oldest known bryozoans from the Lower Ordovician and the advantages and
   disadvantages of micro-CT for the study of Palaeozoic bryozoans are
   discussed. The authorship of Revalotrypidae, which has been
   inconsistently allocated in the literature, is discussed.
C1 Fedorov, Petr V.; St Petersburg State Univ, Inst Earth Sci, St
   Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM p.fedorov@spbu.ru

DT Article
TI A new species of Paramachaerodus (Mammalia, Carnivora, Felidae) from the
   late Miocene of China and Bulgaria, and revision of Promegantereon
   Kretzoi, 1938 and Paramachaerodus Pilgrim, 1913.
AU Li, Yu
   Spassov, Nikolai (liyu@ivpp.ac.cn) 
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 409-426
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New Machairodontinae material from the late Miocene localities of
   Hezheng (China) and Hadjidimovo (Bulgaria) represents a new species of
   Paramachaerodus Pilgrim. Both localities are similar in age and suggest
   that the new species had a very large geographic range extending from
   northwestern China adjacent to the Tibetan Plateau (Gansu Province) to
   southeastern Europe or probably to all of southern Europe. The new
   species-Paramachaerodus transasiaticus sp. nov is characterized by a
   combination of features of "Promegantereon" and Paramachaerodus. This
   specific morphology, as well as the age of the Hezheng and Hadjidimovo
   (early Turolian, after the European Land Mammal Ages) put the new
   species in intermediary position between "Promegantereon" and
   Paramachaerodus. The new felid material give grounds to discuss and
   revise in a new light the systematic and evolution of the
   "Promegantereon"-Paramachaerodus lineage, which should represent
   successive stages of one and the same genus: Paramachaerodus Pilgrim.
C1 Spassov, Nikolai; Bulgarian Acad Sci, Natl Museum Nat Hist, 1 Blvd Tzar
   Osvoboditel, Sofia, 1000, Bulgaria, Bulgaria.
EM liyu@ivpp.ac.cn
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Paramachaerodus; Promegantereon [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Miocene /
   Late Miocene / ]. 
   Paramachaerodus transasiaticus [Gansu /  / new species] [Bulgaria /  / ]
   [Miocene /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Carnivores; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

   Paramachaerodus transasiaticus (Felidae): [Sp nov, Gansu, Miocene, P.
   415; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new Late Miocene ovibovine-like bovid (Bovidae, Mammalia) from the
   Kassandra Peninsula (Chalkidiki, Northern Greece) and implications to
   the phylogeography of the group.
AU Lazaridis, Georgios (geolaz@geo.auth.gr) 
   Kostopoulos, Dimitris S.
   Lyras, George
   Roussiakis, Socrates
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 427-437
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB A new Late Miocene bovid, Urmiatherium kassandriensis sp. nov., from
   Northern Greece is described. The material comes from the Fourka
   locality in the Kassandra Peninsula (Chalkidiki), and the included fauna
   is estimated to be of Vallesian age. The two preserved crania represent
   a medium-sized taxon with short, conical horn cores, a flat cranial roof
   (consisting of the posterior part of the frontals, parietal and
   occipital), thick and porous frontals and pneumatized short parietals,
   an extremely thick basioccipital with voluminous posterior tuberosities
   and accessory articular facets for the atlas. The specialized
   atlanto-occipital joint recalls Pleistocene and extant ovibovines, but
   the braincase structure as a whole and the horn core features closely
   match Late Miocene ovibovine-like taxa, especially Plesiaddax and even
   more Urmiatherium. Nevertheless, the Kassandra bovid differs from
   representatives of both genera in the simpler horn core morphology and
   external brain anatomy. Urmiatherium is known to appear first in China
   and Iran at about 7.8 Ma, whereas its westernmost appearance on Samos
   Island (Greece) is dated much later. The presence of Urmiatherium
   kassandriensis sp. nov. in N. Greece suggests a farther west and earlier
   (Vallesian at least) first appearance of the genus. This would justify a
   basic geographic and phylogenetic split of Urmiatherium into two main
   Turolian lineages: a central-eastern Asian one leading to the sister
   species U. polaki and U. intermedium and a western one leading to U.
   rugosifrons.
C1 Lazaridis, Georgios; Aristotle Univ Thessaloniki, Dept Geol,
   Thessaloniki, 54124, Greece, Greece.
EM geolaz@geo.auth.gr
RI Kostopoulos, Dimitris S./Q-2483-2017; Lyras, George/AAA-3908-2020
OI Lyras, George/0000-0002-4337-6708
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Urmiatherium [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / Significance of new species
   for Miocene; Greece] [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
   Urmiatherium kassandriensis [Greece /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae
OR Urmiatherium (Bovidae). 
   Urmiatherium kassandriensis (Bovidae): [Sp nov, Greece, Miocene, P. 429;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15407036880
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15407036882

TI An enigmatic hawker dragonfly from the Middle Jurassic of China
   (Odonata, Aeshnoptera).
AU Huang, Di-ying
   Nel, Andre (dyhuang@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Cai, Chenyang
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 3
PS 459-462
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB The aeshnopteran Propecymatophlebia magnifica gen. et sp. nov. is
   described from the Middle Jurassic Hiafanggou Formation of Inner
   Mongolia in China, on the basis of a complete forewing. It confirms the
   remarkable palaeodiversity of the stem group of the hawker dragonflies
   in Central Asia in the period between the Middle Jurassic and the Early
   Cretaceous.

AN ZOOR15407038958
DT Article
TI Taxonomy and molecular systematics of the Yellow-green Grosbeak
   Caryothraustes canadensis (Passeriformes: Cardinalidae).
AU Tonetti, Vinicius Rodrigues (vrtonetti@gmail.com) 
   Bocalini, Fernanda
   Silveira, Luis Fabio
   Del-Rio, Glaucia
SO Revista Brasileira de Ornitologia
VL 25
IS 3
PS 176-189
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Yellow-green Grosbeak Caryothraustes canadensis is a South American
   passerine occurring in Amazon and Atlantic Forests. Currently, it
   comprises four subspecies: Caryothraustes canadensis canadensis,
   Caryothraustes canadensis brasiliensis, Caryothraustes canadensis
   frontalis and Caryothraustes canadensis simulans. No study has ever
   revisited its taxonomy, hindering a complete understanding of the
   available diversity in Caryothraustes canadensis complex. We examined
   color and morphometric variation in 259 scientific specimens and
   sequenced the mitochondrial gene ND2 of 29 tissue samples. We also
   quantitatively and qualitatively analyzed 52 spectrograms of vocal
   recordings. Molecular analyzes demonstrated the existence of two
   divergent lineages in C. canadensis complex, one from Amazonia and the
   other in the Atlantic Forest, which can also be distinguished by
   morphometric and plumage characters. Here we propose that the C.
   canadensis complex is composed of two full species: C. canadensis and C.
   brasiliensis. Caryothraustes canadensis frontalis shows no reciprocal
   monophyly in the phylogenetic analyzes, despite having weak plumage
   diagnostic characters; therefore, we suggest it should be considered a
   synonym of C. brasilensis.
C1 Tonetti, Vinicius Rodrigues; Sao Paulo State Univ UNESP, Dept Ecol, Ave
   24A,1515, Rio Claro, SP, BR-13506900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM vrtonetti@gmail.com

   Silveira, Luis/V-6161-2019

   Fernanda/0000-0002-1955-4885; Silveira, Luis/0000-0003-2576-7657

PT J
AN ZOOR15407041256
DT Article
TI On Starengovia Snegovaya, a genus of Asian nemastomatines (Arachnida:
   Opiliones: Nemastomatidae).
AU Martens, Jochen (martens@uni-mainz.de) 
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 124
IS 2
PS 187-201
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two species of the genus Starengovia Snegovaya, 2010 from Kyrgyzstan and
   Pakistan are characterized; S. kirgizica Snegovaya, 2010 is redescribed
   and S. ivanloebli proposed as a new species. They belong to the
   easternmost representatives of the subfamily Nemastomatinae. Both
   species are separated by some 650 km in north to south direction; the
   Pakistan record extends nemastomatine distribution to the northwest of
   the Himalayas. Mediostoma pamiricum Starega, 1986 probably belongs to
   Starengovia as well. Within Nemastomatinae Starengovia displays
   plesiomorphic characters (extremely short glans of penis, armed with
   inconspicuous robust spicules) and apomorphic ones (long, distinctly
   inflated base of penis; large lateral foliate wing-like structures on
   truncus penis). The foliate-wing character is unique among
   Nemastomatidae. Starengovia may represent a relict line in the early
   evolution of nemastomatine harvestmen.
C1 Martens, Jochen; Johannes Gutenberg Univ, Inst Organism & Mol Evolut
   Biol, Mainz, D-55099, Germany, Germany.
EM martens@uni-mainz.de
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0035-418X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Key; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Starengovia [Evolution /  / systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography /
   ] [Asia /  / distribution] [Pakistan /  / New record]. 
   Starengovia ivanloebli [Pakistan /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Mediostoma pamiricum - Starega 1986 (Opiliones): [Taxonomic position,
   Generic placement, p. 200].

   Starengovia ivanloebli (Opiliones): [Sp nov, Pakistan, P. 194]. 
   Starengovia kirgizica - Snegovaya 2010 (Opiliones): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 190; Redescription, P. 190].
